did.unittitle: Douglass family (Detroit and Ann Arbor, Mich.) papers 1812-1911 1837-1900
did.abstract: Papers of Benjamin Douglass and his sons, Samuel T. Douglass, Detroit attorney and jurist, and Silas H. Douglas, professor of chemistry at the University of Michigan, and member of Douglass Houghton's Northern Michigan survey. Correspondence, scrapbooks, letter books, and miscellanea concerning family affairs, business and university activities; also contains records of the Douglass and Walker and Campbell Law Firm; and papers of individual members of Silas Douglasâ€™ family, including his wife Helen Welles Douglas, their children Samuel T. Douglas, Marie Louise Douglas, and Catherine Hulbert Douglas, and other Douglas and Welles family members; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection came from different sources. Marie Louise Douglas (donor no. 183) began donating family papers in 1937. In 1938, she donated the field notes of Silas Douglas from the 1839-40 Douglass Houghton survey. The papers of Samuel T. Douglass came from the U-M library (donor no. 1278). Some of the papers of Samuel T. Douglas were donated by Mrs. E. D. Campbell (donor no. 2916) in 1952.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is retained by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Douglass family (Detroit and Ann Arbor, Mich.) papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Silas H. Douglas (he originally spelled his name Douglass) taught at the University of Michigan from 1844 to 1877. Born in New York state in 1816, he was educated at the Fredonia Academy and at the University of Vermont. He came to Michigan in 1838 and settled in Detroit. He began the study of medicine in the office of Dr. Zina Pitcher, later studying for one term in the Medical Department of the University of Maryland. Douglas accompanied Douglass Houghton on his geological surveys of Michigan in the 1830s. In 1843, he moved to Ann Arbor and began the practice of medicine. A year later he was appointed assistant to Houghton at the U-M and had charge of the work of chemistry during Houghton's absence in the field. After Houghton's death in 1845, Douglas continued in charge of the department and for the remainder of his career worked under different titles in the fields of chemistry, mineralogy, geology, and related subjects. Douglas was largely responsible for the creation of a Chemical Laboratory at the University. This facility was completed and opened for students' work in 1856. Silas Douglas was also founder and officer with the Ann Arbor Gas Company. He died August 26, 1890.

Samuel T. Douglass was an attorney and judge. While serving as judge of the Wayne County circuit court, he became (under the terms of the 1850 state constitution) one of the judges of the Supreme Court. He served here from 1851 to 1857 when he resigned to reenter private practice. Douglass also served several terms on the Detroit Board of Education and was president for one year of the Detroit Young Men's Society.

Silas' son Samuel T. Douglas was a graduate of the University of Michigan and an attorney. When admitted to practice in 1879, he became a member of his uncle's firm (with the name now changed) of Douglas, Bowen & Douglas. The firm had several subsequent name changes with retirements and partner additions. Near the end of his career, the firm name was Douglas, Barbour & Wing. Douglas was long connected with the Washtenaw Gas Company and also served as a director of the Detroit & Security Trust Company.

scopecontent.p: The Douglass Family collection spans the period 1812-1911 and comprises eight linear feet of manuscripts, one linear ft. of photographs, three outsize volumes, and 1 folder of oversize materials. The collection include the papers of Benjamin Douglass and his two sons, Samuel T. (1814-98) a lawyer and Detroit judge, and Silas H. (1816-90), a professor at The University of Michigan. Although Silas came to use the family name of Douglas rather than Douglass, the paper indicate that there was little consistency.

The collection consists of personal and professional correspondence, letterpress books, business and legal papers, scrapbooks, photographs, and family materials. The collection, except for series of photographs and maps, is arranged by family member name.

scopecontent.p: Much of the Benjamin Douglass correspondence is of a personal nature with Lucy Townson Douglass.

The Silas Douglas series consists of correspondence and subject files dealing with family affairs, business matters and, in large part, with his career at the University of Michigan. Of special note is his copy of Douglass Houghton's field notes from his geological survey of the Upper Peninsula and records of the Ann Arbor Gas Company which Douglas founded.

did.unittitle: Resolutions on the death of Silas H. Douglas 1890
Papers concerning diploma fees at the University of Michigan 1860
Subscriptions for addition to the medical building 1864
Certificate to teach and appointment as assistant professor of chemistry signed by Douglass Houghton
Papers concerning St. Andrews Episcopal Church, in Ann Arbor 1878-1887
Records with the Chemical Laboratory at the University of Michigan 1870-1873
Specifications for residence on Washington St. undated
Douglass Houghton field notes from Upper Peninsula geological survey 1839-1840
Inventory of books belonging to the Estate of Douglass Houghton
Papers concerning the case of the Regents of the University of Michigan vs. Douglas and Rose 1876-1878
Receipts and business papers of Silas Douglas
Papers concerning the Sarah A. Byrne account 1877-1888

scopecontent.p: The Helen Welles Douglas papers consists of correspondence received, mainly from her parents John and Sarah Welles

There is a separate series of papers for the children of Silas and Helen Welles Douglas: Alice Helen Douglas, Marie Louise Douglas, Lily C. Douglas, Sarah Douglas, and Catherine (Kate) Hulbert Douglas, and Samuel T. Douglas, an 1873 graduate of the University of Michigan who practiced with his uncle Samuel T. Douglass' law firm in Detroit.

did.unittitle: Letters from Lois Angell McLaughlin to Marie Louise Douglass 1881-1886
Reminiscences and articles on the Douglass family
Class notes for U-M class in rhetoric
Henry W. Douglas [son of Silas] papers 1890, 1917

scopecontent.p: The papers of Samuel T. Douglass consist of correspondence and other materials relating to his legal business in Detroit, but with some items about politics, his farm, and family affairs. Associated with his papers are letterbooks, record books, and other materials of the Douglass and Walker Law Firm

did.unittitle: Record of evidence in cases tried

scopecontent.p: There is also a small Welles Family series containing correspondence and business papers of Helen Welles Douglas parents, John and Sarah Welles. This includes some papers of Henry W. Welles who served some times as treasurer of the University of Michigan. Records of John A. Welles relate to his land holdings, business dealings, and to his estate following his death.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous papers of Henry W. Welles

La Fontaine Farm land books circa 1855-1867
Miscellaneous papers of John A. Welles and the Welles estate

Photos of the home and family of Silas H. Douglas
Miscellaneous daguerreotypes and tintypes of family members.
Map of Saginaw Bay and eastern Michigan shore from Clinton River to Middle Island, by Silas H. Douglas 1838
Map of Lake Huron shore from Au Sable Point to Sturgeon Point 1838
Map of Lake Superior shore from Chocolay River to Granite Pont, copied from original by Douglass Houghton
Map of block bounded by Division, Huron, State, and Washington Streets, Ann Arbor, Mich. undated
Printed map of Forest Hill Cemetery, Ann Arbor, Mich. 1858
Printed map of Emerson's to East Saginaw 1865
